question: Are there any common sustainability topics between Volume B11—Oil & Gas-Exploration & Production and Volume B32—Electric Utilities & Power Generators industries?
optionA: Yes, the common topics are Greenhouse Gas Emissions & Energy Resource Planning and Water Management.
optionB: No, there are no common sustainability topics between the two industries.
optionC: The common topic is only Water Management.
optionD: The common topic is only Greenhouse Gas Emissions & Energy Resource Planning.
optionE: There are no common topics discussed in the given content.
reference_text: ['# IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Electric Utilities & Power Generators', '## Table 1. Sustainability Disclosure Topics & Metrics', '| TOPIC | METRIC |', '|-------|--------|', '| Greenhouse Gas Emissions & Energy Resource Planning | ... |', '| Water Management | ... |']
pairing_explanation: Both industries are central to energy production, and comparisons can highlight differences and synergies in carbon footprints and renewable integration.

question: Give me all the metrics from Table 1 that are in category 'Discussion and Analysis' for Volume B32—Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry.
optionE: There are no 'Discussion and Analysis' metrics for this industry.
reference_text: ['| TOPIC | METRIC | CATEGORY |', '|-------|--------|----------|', '| Greenhouse Gas Emissions & Energy Resource Planning | Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets | Discussion and Analysis |', '| Water Management | Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks | Discussion and Analysis |', '| Nuclear Safety & Emergency Management | Description of efforts to manage nuclear safety and emergency preparedness | Discussion and Analysis |']

question: List the activity metrics for Volume B32—Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry.
optionA: Number of: (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers served, Total electricity delivered to: (1) residential, (2) commercial, (3) industrial, (4) all other retail customers, and (5) wholesale customers, Length of transmission and distribution lines, Total electricity generated, percentage by major energy source, percentage in regulated markets, Total wholesale electricity purchased
optionB: Greenhouse Gas Emissions & Energy Resource Planning, Water Management, End-Use Efficiency & Demand, Nuclear Safety & Emergency Management, Grid Resiliency
optionD: There are no activity metrics listed for this industry.

optionC: Both industries have the same number of 'Quantitative' metrics in Table 1.

optionE: Neither industry has any 'Quantitative' metrics listed in Table 1.

question: When preparing sustainability reports, how do the metrics for measuring greenhouse gas emissions differ between the Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Oil & Gas-Exploration & Production industries?
optionA: The Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry reports total Scope 1 emissions while the Oil & Gas industry breaks it down into different emission sources like flaring, venting, and fugitive emissions.
optionB: There is no difference in how greenhouse gas emissions are measured between the two industries.
optionC: The Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry measures emissions intensity while the Oil & Gas industry measures absolute emissions.
optionD: The Oil & Gas industry only measures methane emissions while the Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry measures all Scope 1 emissions.
optionE: The Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry reports emissions from electricity generation while the Oil & Gas industry reports emissions from exploration and production activities.
